Description: Uber Technologies agreed to pay $20 million to resolve Federal Trade Commission allegations that it misled prospective drivers with exaggerated earning claims and claims about financing through its Vehicle Solutions Program.

Private Litigation Case Title: Sherry Singer et al v. Postmates, Inc.
Ortega et al v. Uber Technologies, Inc. et al
Notes: Covers drivers in New York state.

Court: Superior Court of State of California, County of Los Angeles
Private Litigation Case Title: STEVEN PRICE VS UBER TECHNOLOGIES INC

Secondary Offense: gender, race and national origin discrimination; sexual harassment
Description: The class members are engineers. The settlement amount includes $3 million for legal fees.
Private Litigation Case Title: Del Toro Lopez v. Uber Technologies, Inc.

Description: Uber agreed to pay $7.5 million to settle allegations that it improperly obtain consumer background reports on prospective drivers without their permission.

Private Litigation Case Title: Hood v. Uber Technologies Inc. et al.

Description: Uber Technologies agreed to pay $148 million to settle multistate litigation that it violated data breach reporting and reasonable data security laws in connection with a 2016 breach of driver and customer data. Uber was accused of exposing 57 million users' data and paying hackers to cover up the breach rather than reporting it to proper authorities.
Case alleged that Uber misclassified drivers as independent contractors.
Private Litigation Case Title: O'Connor et al v. Uber Technologies, Inc. et al

Description: Uber agreed to pay $25 million to Los Angeles and San Francisco counties ($15 million suspended) in settlement of allegations it misled customers about the background checks it carried out on its drivers.

Private Litigation Case Title: Dulberg v. Uber Technologies, Inc. et al

Description: Uber Technologies entered into a nationwide agreement to strengthen its business culture against sexual harassment and retaliation.

Info Source: Extracted from a spreadsheet obtained from the NLRB through a Freedom of Information Act request fulfilled on 5/28/2020.

Agency: Washington State Department of Labor & Industries
Info Source: Contained in data obtained on December 4, 2020 in response to an open records request to the agency.

Description: The Office of Labor Standards announced a settlement agreement for $972,075.89 with Postmates, a large food delivery network company. Postmates settled allegations under Seattle's Gig Worker Paid Sick and Safe Time (PSST) Ordinance by paying $949,815.49 in back wages, interest, liquidated damages, and civil penalties to 1,646 gig workers and $22,260.40 in fines to the City of Seattle.

The Office of Labor Standards announced a settlement with Uber to resolve allegations under the Paid Sick and Safe Time (PSST) for Gig Workers Ordinance. Uber paid a total financial remedy of $3,452,686.42 to 15,717 affected workers and $11,130.20 to the City of Seattle.

The Pennsylvania Public Utility Commission approved a $3.5 million settlement with Uber Technologies Inc. and its Pennsylvania subsidiaries, resolving Uber's appeals from Commission orders imposing penalties for operating in 2014 without proper authority.
Multiple violations relating failure to conduct criminal background checks on drivers.

This decision finds that Rasier-CA, LLC (Rasier-CA) is in contempt for failing to comply fully with the Reporting Requirements of ordered in a Decision (D.) 13-09-045. These requirements address accessibility, availability and driver safety information.

The California Public Utilities Commission penalized Rasier-CA, an Uber Technologies subsidiary that provides Transportation Network Company (TNC) services through UberX, $7.6 million for the company's failure to fully and timely comply with the CPUC's reporting requirements.
Company violated CPUC Decision regarding compliance with zero tolerance intoxicating substance policy.

The California Public Utilities Commission approved a settlement agreement with Uber on reporting of data on sexual harassment and assault. Uber will also pay $9 million to support safety and pay a $150,000 fine to the state's General Fund.  initiatives.
